reviewText: Folks, I remember watching this as a kid in 1971 and after seeing some of this again nearly 4 decades later, I can tell you it was dumb then and it is dumb now!Essentially, this is the admittedly imaginative but outrageously stupid series about a ghost named Muggsy and his cat who are trapped in a clock in the 1770s. 200 years later, a group of dune buggy-driving Scooby Doo 70s type teens set the grandfather clock and out comes Muggsy and the cat after all these years to help the kids solve mysteries and the like.Aside from Muggsy's Snagglepuss voice, not much in the way of humor to recommend it. It is really, as Eros says in "Plan 9/Grave Robbers from Outer Space," STEWPID, STEWPID, STEWPID!" Of slight historical interest as it was obiviously meant to capitalize on the then-upcoming bicentenntial.Hanna Barbera was clearly on their downhill post-60s slide on this one. This was not their worst series, however. That (dis)honor belongs to the 1973 politically correct Barney-fied New Zoo Revue fruit loop slop trashterpiece YOGI'S GANG, which they will hopefully not waste on disc.After this, put on some Flintstones and other classic 60s era HB toons (or even the great HONG KONG PHOOEY) get the taste of this monstrosity out of your mouth. Nugget Nose & Mr. Fuddy, anyone?
summary: Aw HELL no! HB on the downhill slide!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The memories I have of Saturday mornings in the 1970s is full of many memories of dozens of cartoons.there were those I watched and the ones I never got to see because they conflicted with my favorites.This show must have conflicted with Scooby Doo or something because I didn't get to see it to often.I started watching the set and boy,what flashbacks.This is one of those funny,spooky shows that came along after Scooby'sSuccess early in the new decade. I've been trying to fill the gaps in memory with purchases of shows from that era and this one fits the bill nicely.From its opening theme I was transported to Saturday AM circa 1971. Not a bad place to be.
summary: The stuff that Saturdays in the 70s is made of!
Title: N/A

reviewText: In the early 70's there was a big colonial revival in anticipation of the bicentennial and the "Funky Phantom" fed right into this. Following the surprising success of  "Scooby Doo" where `meddling kids' and their strange side kick solve crimes Hannah-Barbera created several more Saturday morning cartoon series over the years with a similar theme. One of the more memorable was "The Funky Phantom" where 3 teens and their dog encounter a ghost from the days of the American Revolution and proceed to drive around the countryside solving mysteries that usually revolve around a monster or ghost later revealed to be someone in a mask usually undone when coming up against a real ghost.Part of the problem with FP is that while on Scooby Doo all of the characters contribute to the `entertainment on Funky Phantom most of the humor comes from the ghost, either his antics or malapropisms "Heavens to Betsey Ross!" or mangled history "This is like when I crossed the Potomac with Washington""He crossed the Delaware""Were you there? `Cause I sure was!"The mysteries are no where near as well written as in Scooby Doo (why anyone would be afraid of the `chicken man' is beyond me) and there is an odd tension between the 3 kids of PF as the two guys, voiced well by Mickey Dolenz both try to win the girl's affections and this patter tends to throw off the team feeling compared to SD where the 4 kids just seem friends. Lastly the level of animation is noticeably less than that of Scooby Doo as the HB workshops moved up to producing many more mystery shows for the Saturday morning grind.Overall Funky Phantom is a wonderful reminder of a much simpler time, 1971, when children's cartoons were not just shilling for toy sales. For writing and quality it is not as good as Scooby Doo but it is in the same vein and if you enjoy the original Scooby Doo, then you'll probably like Funky Phantom for the exact same reasons.Oh and the cowardly ghost concept? When compared to later HB fare like "Speedbuggy" "Fang Face" and "Jabberjaw" it's freaking Shakespearian.
Title: N/A

reviewText: 3.5 starsThe Funky Phantom is a cartoon in the vein of Scooby-Doo and Jabberjaw.If you are just starting to collect classic cartoons, wait on this series, unless you are a fan of Micky Dolenz (The Monkees) or love Colonial history. Start first with Scooby-Doo: Where Are You? and Jonny Quest.This is the but... I had purchased two DVD-R releases without problems before I purchased this one. There were problems with 5 episodes on this DVD-R. You couldn't get through an episode without it freezing. This summer I upgraded my ancient DVD player for a 3-D Blu-ray Disc player. This took care of the problems on 4 of the 5 episodes.
